Tracing provenance and chemical weathering changes in Ankara Stream sediments, central Turkey: Geochemical and SreNdePbeO isotopic evidence
Çi gdem Saydam Eker a, *, Ferkan Sipahi a, Mustafa Kemal Gümüş b, €Ozay €Ozkan b
a Department of Geology, Engineering and Natural Sciences Faculty, Gumushane University, 29000 Gumushane, Turkey b Institute of Science and Technology, Gumushane University, 29000 Gumushane, Turkey
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 15 May 2017 Received in revised form 10 November 2017 Accepted 22 November 2017 Available online 24 November 2017
Keywords: Central Turkey Ankara Stream Sediment provenance Weathering Sr-Nd-O-Pb isotopes Climate forcing
* Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: csaydam@gumushane.edu.t
(Ç. Saydam Eker).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jafrearsci.2017.11.034 1464-343X/© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
This study aims to analyze the changes in sediment provenance through the geochemical and SreNdePb eO isotopic composition of the Ankara Stream bed and overbank sediments (ASBS and ASOS) and to examine the weathering and sediment transport processes in response to step climate variability. Major, trace, and rare earth elements, as well as SreNdePbeO isotopic composition, exhibit generally similar variations for the investigated samples. These sediments have relatively high εNd(0) values and low 87Sr/86Sr ratios. Similar Pb isotopic ratios also characterize these sediments but have slightly different d18O isotope values with relatively higher d18O isotope values in the ASBS and lower d18O isotope values in the ASOS samples. Chemical indices indicate lowemoderate chemical weathering in the stepdominated climate. The low average Zr/Sc and Zr/Nb ratios indicate that such geochemical change was dominated by the composition of the source rocks but not sedimentary recycling with zircon enrichment, reflecting first-cycle deposit. Low radiogenic 87Sr/86Sr ratios and negative εNd(0) values indicate that the investigated sediments are relatively derived from young magmatic provinces, which are intermediate sources. Finally, the findings show that the geochemical compositions of the ASBS and ASOS were dominated by the composition of the source materials that originate from Galatia province and Late Cretaceous- Early Tertiary volcanic rocks in central Anatolia. Reasonable semiarid to arid climatic conditions are observed in the region. Active tectonism, increased erosion, and the investigated sediments are also transported rapidly to the stream channel without chemical alteration, and the sediments are the first-cycle products.
© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The elemental and isotopic geochemistry of terrigenous sediments reflects source rock composition, chemical weathering, physical erosion, and hydraulic sorting (McLennan et al., 1993; Grousset et al., 1998; Vital and Stattegger, 2000; Bentahila et al., 2008; Lee et al., 2008; Clift et al., 2008; Dou et al., 2010, 2012; Bouchez et al., 2011; R evillon et al., 2011; Lupker et al., 2012; Li et al., 2015; Dou et al., 2016; Bosia et al., 2016). Most studies show that the isotopic composition of river sediments reflect a drained continental area. The Nd isotopic composition of suspended particles from major rivers correlate with the average age
r, csaydameker@gmail.com
and isotopic tracer of source rocks from drainage basins, apart from the corresponding Nd isotope values for dissolved river loads (Goldstein et al., 1984; Goldstein and Jacobsen, 1987, 1988a, b). Studies demonstrate that Nd isotopes are inconsiderably fractionated during continental weathering and sedimentary processes (Bayon et al., 2015). Sr and O isotopes can also define sedimentary sources (Clayton et al., 1978; Spiers et al., 1984; Yeh and Eslinger, 1986; Goldstein and Jacobsen, 1988a; Nelson and DePaolo, 1988; Chen et al., 1990; Linn and DePaolo, 1993), but are significantly susceptible to variation by weathering and other sedimentary processes. Sr and O isotopes supply additional means of locating source areas; analyzing these isotopes in association with Nd isotopes or other provenance indicators is a method in testing and clarifying provenance interpretations (Heller et al., 1985; Linn and DePaolo, 1993). Inversely, the O isotopic composition in the NdeSr isotope systems is mainly a function of temperature rather
than the age of the rock formation. Igneous rocks typically crystallize at high temperatures and have relatively uniform d18O values ofþ6 toþ11. Sedimentary rocks have high d18O values, which range from approximately þ10% to þ40% (Hoefs, 1987) because these rocks include autogenic or detrital minerals that form at low temperatures (Linn and DePaolo, 1993).
This study aims to compare the stream and Pleistocene-aged (Akyürek et al., 1997; Bilgin et al., 2009) overbank sediments of Ankara Stream (ASBS and ASOS) in central Turkey in the AlpineHimalayan system because of the well-preserved overbank sediments. Major elements, trace elements, and rare earth elements (REE) and SreNdePbeO isotopes have been investigated for the ASBS and ASOS to evaluate the present weathering, sedimentary cycle, provenance characteristics, erosion processes, and weathering mechanisms in the region. Sedimentary cycle history, sediment sources, and SreNdePbeO isotopic composition were also analyzed to obtain information on the chemical weathering degree.

sections.heading: 2. Geological and hydrographic background
sections.text:
The investigated area is in the Sakarya Continent, which represents the southern margin of Eurasia in the north, and the AnatolideeTauride block that includes the Central Anatolian Crystalline Complex in the south (Fig. 1). Carboniferous high-grade metamorphic rocks constitute the continental basement of the Sakarya Continent (Duru et al., 2004; Okay et al., 2006; Nzegge et al., 2006; Topuz et al., 2007; Sarifakioglu et al., 2014). The Triassic Karakaya
Complex tectonically overlies the crystalline basement units (Tekeli, 1981). This area contains the Lower Karakaya, including metabasite, marble, and phyllite rocks, and Upper Karakaya comprising unmetamorphosed clastic and basic volcanic rocks with blocks of Carboniferous and Permian neritic limestones (Bing€ol et al., 1975; Okay et al., 2002; Okay and G€oncüo glu, 2004; Sarifakioglu et al., 2014). Jura-aged clastic deposits and limestones lie conformably on the Karakaya Complex in the Ankara region. The Late Cretaceous granitoids, including monzonite and syenite supersuites, and the PaleoceneeEocene volcanic, volcaniclastic, and carbonate rocks crosscut and overlie, respectively, the crystalline basement units of the Central Anatolia Crystalline Complex (Güleç, 1994; Boztu g, 2000; Kadıo glu et al., 2003, 2006; _Ilbeyli et al., 2004; Sarifakioglu et al., 2014). OligoceneeMiocene evaporates, continental clastic rocks, MioceneePliocene continental clastics, and volcanic rocks and Pleistocene aged alluvium cover the bottom units (Akyürek et al., 1997; Bilgin et al., 2009) (Fig. 1).
Ankara Stream is formed by the combination of the Çubuk and Hatip Streams in the Etlik site and passes through Ankara, which is one of the most populated and industrialized cities in Turkey, and flow into Sakarya River. The investigated region is dominated by step climate, with annual rainfall of 300 mme500 mm. Rain everywhere is seasonal, with the maximum annual rainfall occurring during spring, whereas the minimum annual rainfall occurring during summer. Temperature in the study area varies from approximately 20 Ce30 C in summer and from approximately 0 C to 5 C inwinter, with obvious winter and summer, as well as
Bilgin et al. (2009)) and location map of the study area and some of the major tectonic nd limestones, 3- Paleocene-Eocene volcanic, volcanoclastic and carbonate rocks, 4- tal clastic and volcanic rocks, 6- Pleistocene overbank sediments, 7- Slope rubble.
day and night, differences. Vegetation is weak and dominated by steppe vegetation.

sections.heading: 3.1. Sampling
sections.text: A total of 35 sampling locations were identified throughout the Ankara Stream for the stream sediments, and a total of 35 sampling locations were identified for the Pleistocene-aged overbank sediments. The sampling locations are shown in Fig. 1. The samples were collected in March 2015 as representatives of low-flow conditions (i.e., no significant rainfall in the previous three weeks). The stream sediment samples were obtained from the stream channel at 0e13 cm depths using a small dredge. The thickness of the Pleistocene-aged overbank sediments ranged from approximately 2 me4.5 m. A total of 70 sediment samples were collected. The samples were air dried in the laboratory prior to analytical analysis. Then, the samples were homogenized and crushed to approximately 200 mesh size using an agate mortar.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Whole-rock major and trace element analyses
sections.text:
Major and trace elements were determined at the commercial
Acme Analytical Laboratories Ltd. in Vancouver, Canada. The major and trace element compositions were measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) using 0.2 g of sediment fused with 1.5 g of LiBO2 dissolved in 100 mL of 5% HNO3. Ignition loss was determined using dried samples heated to a temperature of 1000 C for 15 min. REE analysis was conducted by ICP-MS at ACME. The detection limits were in the range of 0.001 wt % to 0.1 wt% for major element oxides and 0.1 ppme10 ppm for trace elements. Calibration and verification standards together with reagent blanks were added to the sample sequences. STD SO18 was certified in-house against 38 certified reference materials, including CANMET SY-4 and USGS AGV-1, G-2, GSP-2, and W-2 as known external standards. The analytical accuracy is better than 4%.
Whole-rock major, trace and rare earth element analyses were separately applied to 70 sediment samples (i.e., stream sediments¼ 35, Pleistocene-aged overbank sediments¼ 35) in this study.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Sr-Nd isotopic analyses
sections.text:
Isotopic analyses of Sr and Nd were performed at the Depart-
ment of Geological Sciences, New Mexico State University. All isotopic measurements were made by TIMS, on a VG Sector 30 mass spectrometer. All samples analyzed were loaded onto rhenium filaments on either Cathodian beads (single filament only) or on the side filament of a triple filament assembly. Reproducibility of the of the 87Rb/86Sr and 147Sm/144Nd ratios are within 0.3%, and the 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd ratios are within ±0.000025 and ± 0.00003, respectively. The detailed analytical procedures for Srand Nd isotopic measurements are given Ramos (1992). Sr-Nd isotopic analyses was used for 14 (7 samples from stream sediments, 7 samples from overbank sediments). εNd(0) was calculated by utilizing the following formula (CHUR's current 143Nd/144Nd value is assumed 0.512638, Zhang and Wang, 2001):
εNdð0Þ ð143Nd=144NdÞ of sample ð143Nd=144NdÞ of CHUR 1
104 (1)

sections.heading: 3.2.3. O isotopic analyses
sections.text:
Oxygen was extracted from 5 mg samples at 550e600 C ac-
cording to the conventional BrF5 procedure of Clayton and Mayeda (1963) and analyzed on Thermo-Finnigan Delta plusXP Continuous e Flow Isotope e Ratio Mass Spectrometer (CF-IRMS). d18O values are reported using the delta (d) notationin units of permil (‰) standard relative to Vienna Standard Mean Ocean Water (VSMOW) international standard, with a precision of 0.1‰. O isotopic analyse was performed on 7 samples from stream sediments and 7 samples from overbank sediments.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Pb isotopic analyses
sections.text:
Isotopic analysis of Pb was performed at the commercial Acme
Analytical Laboratories Ltd. in Vancouver, Canada. The prepared sample is digested with a modified aqua regia solution of equal parts concentrated HCl, HNO3, and DI H2O for 1 h in a heating block or a hot water bath. The sample is made up to volume with dilute HCl. Sample splits of 0.5, 15, or 30 g were analyzed. Pb isotope addons (þISO) Pb204, Pb206, Pb207, and Pb208 are suitable for geochemical exploration of U and other commodities where gross differences in natural to radiogenic Pb ratios are beneficial. Isotope values can be obtained from the concentrations and intensities. Sample splits of 0.5, 15, or 30 g were analyzed. Pb isotopic analyses were performed on 10 samples from stream sediments and 10 samples from overbank sediments.

sections.heading: 3.3. Geochemical proxies (CIA, WIP, and ICV) calculation
sections.text: The chemical index of alteration (CIA) [CIA ¼ Al2O3/ (Al2O3 þ CaO*þ Na2Oþ K2O) 100 (Nesbitt and Young, 1982)], the weathering index of Parker (WIP) [WIP ¼ 100 CaO*/0.7 þ 2Na2O/ 0.35 þ 2K2O/0.25 þ MgO/0.9 (Parker, 1970)], and the index of compositional variability (ICV) [ICV ¼ Fe2O3 þ K2O þ Na2O þ CaO* þ MgO þ TiO2/Al2O3 (Cullers and Podkovyrov, 2002); CaO* represents CaO of the silicate fraction only; CIA, WIP, and ICV are calculated using the molecular proportions of the mobile alkali and alkaline earth elements] of clastic rocks are commonly used as indicators of the extent of weathering of their source areas. The sediments with high ICV may represent first-cycle deposits, whereas the sediments with low ICV values (<1) may be derived from mature sediments with a high percentage of clay minerals (Kamp and Leake, 1985). Geochemical proxies consisting CIA and Al/K ratios have been applied to define the intensity of alteration in sediment during chemical weathering and to establish any possible link with climate records (Wei et al., 2004; D. K. Hu et al., 2012, 2013; Limmer et al., 2012; Dou et al., 2016). The K tends to be enriched in weathering product during moderate weathering but depleted during extreme weathering (Nesbitt et al., 1980; Condie et al., 1995), whereas Al is relatively conservative during theweathering process (Dou et al., 2016). Thus, the high Al/K ratio in sediments, which indicate extreme chemical weathering, is evaluated (Wei et al., 2006). In the current study, these chemical indices are used to interpret the weathering intensity recorded in the investigated sediments and to investigate the case for climate forcing.

sections.heading: 5.1. Provenance characteristics
sections.text:
The geochemical records in the Ankara Stream sediments indicate that the geochemical compositions of ASBS and ASOS were dominated by the composition of the same source materials. The Al2O3/TiO2 ratios of the ASBS and ASOS range from 12.2 to 15.5 and from 12.2 to 15.0, respectively. The Th/Sc, La/Sc, and Co/Th ratios of the ASBS are similar to the Th/Sc, La/Sc, and Co/Th ratios of the ASOS (Table 2). The La/Sc and Co/Th ratios of the samples are higher than that of the UCC, whereas the Th/Sc ratios of the samples are lower than that of the UCC (Table 2). The average (La/Yb)N ratios of the ASBS and ASOS samples are 12.6 and 13.0, respectively. The average (Gd/Yb)N ratio is 1.8 in the ASBS and ASOS (Table 2). The calculated average Eu/Eu* ratios are 0.84 in ASBS and 0.86 in ASOS; therefore, the investigated samples have slightly negative Eu anomaly.
Whole rock Sr-Nd isotopic data of the ASBS are similar to those of ASOS, and the sediments have unradiogenic Sr and Nd isotopic compositions. The isotopic data of the investigated samples are compared with several relevant source areas in the Alpine-
sediments. UCC normalizing values are from Taylor and McLennan (1985).
Himalayan system using a 87Sr/86Sr versus εNd(0) diagram (Fig. 8). The source areas include the tertiary volcanism of the Galatia province (The Early Miocene volcanics are predominantly trachyandesites and dasites with minor rhyolite and alkali basalts in north-west central Anatolia, Turkey, from Wilson et al., 1997), volcanic rocks (Late Cretaceous- Early Tertiary volcanics are predominantly trachyandesites and trachybasalts in central Anatolia, Turkey from Alpaslan et al., 2004), Late Cretaceous granitoids (Central Anatolia, Turkey, from K€oksal and G€oncüo glu, 2007), Greater Himalaya (GH), Tethyan Himalaya (TH, mainly a PlaeozoicEocene sedimentary sucession which was deposited on the northern passive margin of India) and Lesser Himalaya (LH, mainly Proterozoic metasedimentary sequence, typ-deposited on Indian crust) (Bracciali et al., 2015). According to plotted in a Sr-Nd isotope mixing diagram (Fig. 8), investigated sediments are mainly derived from Galatia province and Late Cretaceous- Early Tertiary volcanic rocks erosion. This phenomenon defines that the ASBS and ASOS are relatively derived from young magmatic provinces and the low radiogenic 87Sr/86Sr ratios are consistent with the occurrence of these provinces.
All samples are similar in general distribution when the major element, trace element, and REE components of the ASBS are compared with that of the ASOS. These samples have lower Al/Si, Th/Sc, Zr/Sc, and Eu*/Eu ratios and higher (La/Yb)N and Co/Th ratios (Table 2). ASBS and ASOS have generally similar Pb isotopic ratios and relatively high εNd(0) values and low 87Sr/86Sr ratios. The DεNd(ASBS ASOS) values are between 0.04 and 0.41 (<1; Table 3), thereby confirming that stream and overbank sediments are derived from similar sources. d18O exhibits no correlation with CIA in ASBS, but has a positive correlation with CIA in ASOS (Fig. 10c). High d18O values are believed to be controlled by authigenic and detrital minerals in the ASBS and partial chemical weathering and authigenic and detrital minerals in the ASOS.
Finally, the REE average values of ASBS and ASOS normalized the Post-Archean Australian Shale (PAAS) are compared with the UCC, lower continental crust (LCC), and mixing composition (Fig. 9). The REE distribution of ASBS and ASOS are similar to the LREE distribution of the UCC, but the LREEs of ASBS and ASOS are slightly depleted compared with the LREEs of the UCC (except La). The HREE distribution of the investigated sediments are similar to the
HREE distribution of the LCC, but some of these elements of the HREE (i.e., Tm, Yb, and Lu) are slightly enriched compared with the elements of the LCC. The geochemical and isotopic data indicate that ASBS and ASOS are likely derived from particle to intermediate sources, just like Galatia province and Late Cretaceous- Early Tertiary volcanic rocks.
5.2. Chemical weathering
Geochemical parameters provided from the analysis of terrigenous sediments are fully applied to conclude weathering and paleo-weathering conditions in source areas. The concentration of chemical elements in sediments and sedimentary rocks is forced by the original mineralogy of source rocks, and is in this way provenance-addicted. Therefore, chemical indices of weathering may not externalize weathering only, or even mainly (Garzanti and Resentini, 2016).
Chemical parameters, such as CIA values, are commonly used to induce weathering conditions in source areas, although these parameters are clearly controlled by the mineralogy of source rocks and succession from previous sedimentary cycles (Borges et al., 2008; Garzanti and Resentini, 2016; Garzanti et al., 2016). The WIP and ICV values of clastic rocks are commonly used as indicators of the extent of weathering of their source areas. The average values of the CIA, WIP, and ICV of ASBS and ASOS are 58, 56, 2.11 and 59, 56, 2.05, respectively (Table 2). The sediments with high ICV may represent first-cycle deposits, whereas the sediments with low ICV values (<1) may be derived from mature sediments with a high percentage of clay minerals (Kamp and Leake, 1985). From the ICV values, the investigated sediments were derived from a source compositionally dominated by an immature material with inadequate alumina-rich minerals. The first-cycle muds of the CIA orWIP ratios range from 1 to 2 (Garzanti et al., 2014). In the investigated samples, the average CIA/WIP ratios of the ASBS and ASOS samples are 1.03 and 1.05, respectively, thereby indicating large first-cycle sediments. This result is also supported by the low CIA values because the CIA of sediments is approximately 50 for the first-cycle sediments that were dominantly derived from physically weathered igneous rocks (Nesbitt and Young, 1984). A low CIA value (i.e., less than 65) is consistent with the high mechanical erosion rates
observed in tectonically active settings (Blatt et al., 1980; Linn and DePaolo, 1993). Furthermore, geochemical proxy, such as Al/K ratio, has been applied to assess the intensity of alteration in sediment during chemical weathering and to define any possible link with
monsoon climate records (Wei et al., 2004; Hu et al., 2012, 2013; Limmer et al., 2012; Dou et al., 2016). Therefore, a high Al/K ratio in sediments is interpreted to indicate extreme chemical weathering (Wei et al., 2006; Dou et al., 2016). The average Al/K ratios of
ASBS and ASOS are relatively high at 3.9 and 4.1, respectively. Therefore, the Al/K ratios in the stream sediments do not only reflect chemical weathering intensity but also the sediment provenance. The chemical weathering proxies, such as Al/K and CIA, are somewhat higher during the Pleistocene than the present, apparently indicating that ASOS are more chemically altered than ASBS. The geochemical proxies, including Al/K ratios and CIA values of the fine-grained sediments, can also better reflect the integrated silicateweathering intensity than sandy soil (Shao et al., 2012; Bi et al., 2015; Dou et al., 2016). In this study, the Al/Si ratios show a positive correlation with CIA in ASBS and ASOS (r ¼ 0.58 and 0.79, respectively; Fig. 10a) and a high positive correlation with Al/K (r ¼ 0.82 and 0.93, respectively; Fig. 10b). Therefore, in the investigated sediments, high silicate weathering is observed in fine-grained sediments. The O isotopic composition of sedimentary rocks is a function of the composition of the source rock and the amount of alteration in d18O produced duringweathering and diagenesis (Linn and DePaolo, 1993). For this reason, sedimentary rocks are high in d18O and vary by approximately þ10% and þ40% (Hoefs, 1987) because they contain detrital or autogenic minerals that form at low temperatures (Linn and DePaolo, 1993). d18O exhibits a positive correlation with CIA in ASOS (r ¼ 0.60; Fig. 10c), but exhibits no
correlationwith CIA in ASBS (r¼ 0.16; Fig.10c). In this context, the high d18O values are believed to be controlled by autogenic and detrital minerals in the ASBS and partial chemical weathering and autogenic and detrital minerals in the ASOS. Climate (mean precipitation and temperature) has long been regarded as the primary control (Berner and Berner, 1997; Dou et al., 2016) although the exciting mechanisms for chemical weathering are still discussed, particularly in the monsoon-dominated river basins (Li and Yang, 2010; Shao et al., 2012; Bi et al., 2015; Wan et al., 2015; Dou et al., 2016). High precipitation and wetter climate may increase the rate/intensity of chemical weathering, whereas either low precipitation and/or temperature can decrease theweathering rate/ intensity (White and Blum, 1995; West et al., 2005). Weathering intensity is also closely related to vegetation and runoff because vegetation keeps moisture for chemical reactions, whereas runoff affects the rates of chemical and mechanical denudations (Summerfield and Hulton, 1994; Liu et al., 2008). Ankara Stream basin mainly experiences a step climate with hot temperature and aridesemiarid during summer, cold temperature, and snow during winters. The annual runoff ranging from 300 mm to 500 mm is slightly vegetated through all seasons. The temperature difference between day and night in arid climate is potentially responsible for
stronger physical weathering in the Ankara Stream basin. Tectonic processes can increase the exposure of fresh, unaltered rock surfaces. The tectonic uplift (Vallakian Phase; Erol, 1961) has dramatically increased the slope of central Turkey.

sections.heading: 5.3. Sedimentary sorting and recycling
sections.text:
The Th/Sc ratio does not change considerably during sedimentary recycling (Cullers, 1994), whereas the Zr/Sc ratio increases significantly during the same process. By contrast, heavy minerals (e.g., zircon) generally dominate with high Zr concentrations or GdN/YbN ratios; the enrichment of these minerals during sediment transport can influence the entire rock geochemistry (McLennan, 1989; Wang et al., 2014). Thus, the Th/Sc ratios can be applied in
tracing sedimentary provenance, and the high Zr/Sc ratios can be considered a useful indicator of zircon enrichment (McLennan, 1989; Wang et al., 2014). The average Zr/Sc, Th/Sc, and GdN/YbN ratios of the ASBS are 16.4, 0.89, and 1.8, respectively. The average Zr/Sc, Th/Sc, and GdN/YbN ratios of the ASOS are 15.2, 0.87, and 1.8,
respectively. These ratios show that no significant enrichment occurred in the heavy minerals in the ASBS and ASOS. The investigated sediments also exhibit a strong positive correlation in the Th/Sc versus Zr/Sc diagram (Fig. 11), thereby indicating that geochemical change was dominated by the composition of the source rocks but not sedimentary recyclingwith zircon enrichment. The Zr or Nb ratios of the investigated samples are low (average Zr/ Nb ratios are 10.5 for ASBS and 9.6 for ASOS) according to the average Zr/Nb ratio of UCC (15.8) (McLennan, 2001; Klaver et al., 2015), which supports that no zircon enrichment occurred. Similarly, the Th/U ratio increased because of the successive cycles of weathering and redeposition; this result is a good indicator of these processes (Wang et al., 2014). The average Th/U ratios are 3.5 in ASBS and 4.3 in ASOS; these ratios indicate a relatively simple cycling history.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
The current study presents the geochemical and SreNdePbeO isotopic composition of detrital sediments from the ASBS and ASOS, analyzes the sediment provenance, and investigates the response of chemical weathering and physical erosion in the source area to the changes of central Turkey step climate.
Chemical elements, including major elements, trace elements, and REE and SreNdePbeO isotopes indicate generally similar distribution for the sediments from Ankara Stream. ASBS and ASOS underwent lowemoderate chemical weathering. Moreover, d18O exhibits a positive correlation with CIA in ASOS, but exhibits no correlation with CIA in ASBS. Therefore, the high d18O values are believed to be controlled by autogenic and detrital minerals in ASBS, partial chemical weathering, and autogenic and detrital minerals in ASOS. ASBS and ASOS underwent a relatively simple sedimentary cycling history. DεNd(ASBS ASOS) values are lower than 1, thereby confirming that stream sediments are derived from similar sources.
The geochemical records in the Ankara Stream sediments indicate that the geochemical compositions of ASBS and ASOS were dominated by the composition of the source materials that originate from Galatia province and Late Cretaceous- Early Tertiary volcanic rocks in central Anatolia. Reasonable semiarid to arid climatic conditions in the region, as well as active tectonism and increased erosion, exist. Moreover, the investigated sediments are transported rapidly to the stream channel without chemical
alteration, and the sediments are the first-cycle products.
Acknowledgments
This study was funded by The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TÜB_ITAK Grant No: 114Y803). We gratefully acknowledge Editor Dr. Damien Delvaux for editorial handling. The authors thanks to both anonymous reviewers for his/ her constructive comments andsuggestions to improve the manuscript.

abstractText: This study aims to analyze the changes in sediment provenance through the geochemical and SreNdePb eO isotopic composition of the Ankara Stream bed and overbank sediments (ASBS and ASOS) and to examine the weathering and sediment transport processes in response to step climate variability. Major, trace, and rare earth elements, as well as SreNdePbeO isotopic composition, exhibit generally similar variations for the investigated samples. These sediments have relatively high εNd(0) values and low 87Sr/86Sr ratios. Similar Pb isotopic ratios also characterize these sediments but have slightly different d18O isotope values with relatively higher d18O isotope values in the ASBS and lower d18O isotope values in the ASOS samples. Chemical indices indicate lowemoderate chemical weathering in the stepdominated climate. The low average Zr/Sc and Zr/Nb ratios indicate that such geochemical change was dominated by the composition of the source rocks but not sedimentary recycling with zircon enrichment, reflecting first-cycle deposit. Low radiogenic 87Sr/86Sr ratios and negative εNd(0) values indicate that the investigated sediments are relatively derived from young magmatic provinces, which are intermediate sources. Finally, the findings show that the geochemical compositions of the ASBS and ASOS were dominated by the composition of the source materials that originate from Galatia province and Late CretaceousEarly Tertiary volcanic rocks in central Anatolia. Reasonable semiarid to arid climatic conditions are observed in the region. Active tectonism, increased erosion, and the investigated sediments are also transported rapidly to the stream channel without chemical alteration, and the sediments are the first-cycle products. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
title: Tracing provenance and chemical weathering changes in Ankara Stream sediments, central Turkey: Geochemical and Sr-Nd-Pb-O isotopic evidence
